extendedMetadata.name: Objective
extendedMetadata.value: LO: 7.5: Why were some Federalists willing to sacrifice political freedoms for party advantage?,

subject: US History
metadata.bookAuthor: H. W. Brands; T. H. Breen; R. Hal Williams; Ariela J. Gros
metadata.title: POST 07 18

config.question: In the long term, what was the significance of the election of 1800?

choices.content: It showed that political dissent did not always lead to political extremism.
It showed that the Federalists had lost power because of their foreign policies.
It showed that political dissent was accompanied by political extremism and violence.
It showed that interference by foreign diplomats in internal affairs would not be supported by American citizens.

answer_3.response: Consider This: Jefferson attempted to quiet partisan fears. “We are all republicans; we are all federalists,” the new president declared. By this statement, he did not mean to suggest that party differences were no longer important. Jefferson reminded his audience that whatever the politicians might say, the people shared a deep commitment to a federal union based on republican ideals set forth during the American Revolution. See L.O. 7.5 Why were some Federalists willing to sacrifice political freedoms for party advantage?
